Team members can add cards here for any of the following:

- **Unity guideline suggestions**: Are there any unspoken Unity-specific rules not incorporated into the [Unity Team Guide](https://www.raywenderlich.com/tutorial-team/unity-team-guide) or do you think something can be improved? Add it here!
- **3D model requests**: Do you want to see some specific models added to the [model repo](https://github.com/raywenderlich/raze-models)? Add a card for what kind of models you want with a detailed explanation and some reference pictures.  
- **Unity asset requests**: Would you like certain assets like scripts, sounds, fonts, shaders or template projects added to the [Unity Assets repo](https://github.com/raywenderlich/Unity-Assets)? Create a new card and either the asset you want to see added, or a request for what you want someone else to create and add.  
- **Style guide requests**: Did I forget to add something to the [English](https://github.com/raywenderlich/english-style-guide) or [C# style guide](https://github.com/raywenderlich/c-sharp-style-guide) or do you have suggestions for improvements? Add a card about it here.

## Artwork

**Artwork Request:** <TBD by Illustration Team Lead>

## Brief

**Working Title:** 

*In Depth: Unity's Particle System"
 *Advanced Particles in Unity"

**Audience Level:**  Intermediate

**Style:** How-To

**Motivation:**
As we are going to freshen the previous tutorial, we need to stay up to date with new and more advanced technics. Although VFX graph is on, Shuriken continues to be pretty much the standard because it’s easy, quick and powerful. So, it’s time to give it a fresh in-depth show off.
Remember that this tutorial builds up on top of the previous tutorial. So, you can skip certain basic explanations altogether. 
For this API it’s important to showcase the main features that are considered advanced: 
*Lighting: how to use different materials to your advantage. Normals. Transparencies. Adding lights or trails to the particles.
*Chaining: how to make a progression reaction of different shuriken acting as one.  Sub-emitters.
*Sheet animations: self-explanatory. It needn’t be a realistic manta flow intergalactic fire explosion; just a sweet idea will work fine. 
* Mesh instantiation: This can work very well in tune with chaining.
Keep in mind this is a “visual” tutorial. If you do super advance cool stuff like instantiating semitransparent ice with UV animation, masks and lights, people are going to lose their minds for your tutorial.
Note: Also, if you can add, somehow, more: Force field and Particle Physics / Collision are perfect.

**Key Ideas, APIs, and Techniques:**
I would suggest making a small place where to show the different effects. Remember: Shininess! Glossiness! Smoothness! Are your friends. Make every single floor and walls extra hyper shiny, so reflections work in your advantage.  Try to hide the empty default background.
Be ready to create or ask for: masks, materials that highlight normal maps, simple textures animations. Be ready for lots of trial and error.
- These are some ideas that can be added. People always ask how to create:
	*Bubbles
	*Material with normals
	*Dissolve
	*Heat (blurry images)
	*Inverse colors
	*Discolor
	*Chain of effects
	*Texture sheet animations
	*Fireworks
	*Lights	
Remember there’s a previous tutorial, so you don’t need to specify every single thing. You can build on top of it.

**Sample App Idea:**
I would suggest different approaches:
A top-down small game would be the best of the best.
It would be great if a character activates different powers/effects when entering a trigger.

or

If the previous ideas fail, it would be cool to trigger everything using buttons in the UI. That’s simple enough.
Everything outside VFX should be part of the starter project. For instance, no one would like to waste time painting a mask for this tutorial. Mind that!

**References:**
Don’t waste your time at Unity.com, but visit Unity Asset Store for reference. 

This is a free Unity asset pack for reference too: 
https://assetstore.unity.com/packages/essentials/tutorial-projects/unity-particle-pack-127325

This guy just hit the spot
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=yQkG4p3bizA

Look for Mirza. He is a lovely folk full of good tutorials.

This is a pack of particles that people love.
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Wqj7hXePTn8

We cannot forget about Brackeys.
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=FEA1wTMJAR0


Cast your might!

--------------------------------

This topic delves more deeply into Unity particle systems and explains how to use them in more advanced ways. It builds upon this tutorial: https://www.raywenderlich.com/138-introduction-to-unity-particle-systems

## Artwork

**Artwork Request:** <TBD by Illustration Team Lead>

## Brief

**Working Title:** 
D&D (Dungeons and Dragons) is not cool enough, we need something else:
o	R&R (Reyes and Renderliches [reɪes n ɹəndɜːlixs])
o	R&D (Wenderlich and Dice)
o	Dicer (Life is nicer with dicer)

**Audience Level:**  Beginner

**Style:** How-To

**Motivation:**
Whether a simple app to play RPGs in real life or just a base system for something bigger, a 3D dice rolling API always comes in handy. Whether it’s a board game, a card game, or one of those 704 games grandparents used to play, everybody needs dice. 
Dice are an engaging tool that can promote competition or collaboration… but mostly drama. They are the ultimate interface for decision-making. Life is nicer with dice. Dice are so cool that they should have their own plural inflection. If you think about it, they can be their own game.
Based on different forums, this type of APIs looks so simple at first sight… but when the time comes, the beginner programmer ends up scratching his head: “how on earth do I get the number on top?”. So, the idea, as everything we do at R&R… is to make it easy, but stylish.
You can teach about local and world positions, how to compare heights, some UI features, the use of Rigidbodies and forces, changing colors of textures based on certain condition and more.
This could be a very nice first app for anyone.

**Key Ideas, APIs, and Techniques:**
-If you add empties to the faces of the dice, you can get information by checking the world Y position. It seems to be the quickest and easiest way to start.
-If instead you add a simple texture as a transparent mask on top of the faces, you can change the color of the number that is facing up to add extra flavor. That same texture can be the world Y position.
-Add a UI with some buttons representing the different type of dice: D20, D8 and D4, so the player can select one. Maybe those buttons only instantiate dice, and another button throws to them.
-Mind how you use Rigidbodies forces. An unrealistic toss will ruin the magic.
-A reset/start again button would be nice.
-Make the UI to report info about the dice; for instance, the sum of all numbers. You can also show when dice are rolling and when they aren’t.
-Remember to prevent dice to fall outside the tray.

[Don’t doubt to ask me or any other member for help if you need 3D assets]

**Sample App Idea:**
The idea is to design a tabletop game environment: a table with some assets on it would be great to imitate a real-world table. Add some assets: maps, glasses, other 'static' dice, a board, cards, pencils, or whatever you can add to set the mood. Don’t forget a dice tray.
If you have the time, don’t just leave the ugly standard Unity clouds background. As the programming part may be simple, it’s a great idea to compensate: most of other tutorials really-really-really lack some good visual content. 
Adding text and messages would definitely add extra flavor to the scene.
In any case, it’s up to you if you want to create your own dice. If you do, show the readers how to do it.
Encourage the reader to allot some time to create their own scene by making small changes. That could generate good feedback.

**References:**
This could be your starting point:
https://www.youtube.com/watch?time_continue=125&v=nCowrvfOr3Q&feature=emb_title

This is a full DnD tabletop simulator, just for reference. 
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=7wmam3mKIss

This is a beautiful set:
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=9fvOPokPrN8

----------
A simple "normal" six sided die tutorial might be too simplistic. How give this one some tabletop flavor and add a few other ones like a D20, D8 and a D4? That way we can theme the article with some D&D (for example) goodness.

## Artwork

**Artwork Request:** <TBD by Illustration Team Lead>

## Brief

**Working Title:** How to make a RPG Inventory UI System in Unity

**Audience Level:**  Intermediate

**Style:** Core Concept

**Motivation:**

Building a simple UI system is relatively easy in Unity. But it's a bit of a leap when taking UI interactions to the next level. One of the most common thing people immediately think of trying to implement is a player inventory system. But it can quickly become a daunting challenge if all you know is the base UI components. 

The great thing about the UnityUI system is that it is very easy to extend to create your own UI components. These can have unique ways that they display and/or handle interactions. 

**Key Ideas, APIs, and Techniques:**

- How to create your own Graphic components.
- UIEvents and Event Triggers.
- How to work with IPointerEvents, and the advantage over using base Events and Triggers.

**Sample App Idea:**

How about the classic, RPG inventory management system. Working with a player inventory and a random chest, build the UI system the represents all items in each inventory, and can handle dragging items from one to the other. It should include highlight states, animation when clicking and dragging items, and a bonus is a system that recognises dropping in an invalid location.

Suggested components to create:

 - Inventory `Slot`.
 - Inventory `Item`.
 -- Setting that as a reusable dynamic prefab, perhaps that auto changes background color depending on the item type. 
 - The `Item` would need to implement IPointer methods to handle interaction.
 -- Quick actions such as move one, more stack could be a stretch goal beyond the simple drag and drop.

**References:**

- Perhaps use Valheim, a #madewithunity game, as an example of a working inventory system.
- The Unity UI Extensions library is a great place to see how people have extended the Unity UI system https://bitbucket.org/UnityUIExtensions/unity-ui-extensions/wiki/Home
- And of course, exploring the Unity UI source is a great learning place https://github.com/Unity-Technologies/uGUI

Topic Master: 	mFuentes

## Artwork

**Artwork Request:** <TBD by Illustration Team Lead>

## Brief

**Working Title:** 	Introduction to Asynchronous Programming in Unity 3D
**Audience Level:**  	Intermediate-Advanced
**Style:** 		Core Concept
**Motivation:**

We know that Unity has its own synchronization context and organizes your code on the main thread linearly. In case you need to wait for a task, spread a task in multiple frames, do more than one thing at a time or need to load a big chunk of data, Unity’s Coroutines could be more of a headache than a solution. Coupled with programmers’ reluctance to change, the whole process can be really annoying. Coroutines are a very useful and intelligent way of putting IEnumerators to good use; but it’s not the right tool for the right job in complex situations.

Since 2016, Unity has been restructuring their systems and APIs. Addressables, for instance, were structured following an Asynchronous model instead of Coroutines or Multithreading. Why? Because Async programming is the right tool for that job. This is why we need Asynchronous programming.

The main purpose of this tutorial is to present Async programming as a new tool, clarifying and demystifying it so everybody can make use of it. As an introductory article, it should explain most of the Async methods and declarations with very simple, short and visual examples through an API. As most articles out there are mostly theoretical or abstract (the very opposite of a tool), the tutorial should be straightforward, practical, easy to digest and, if possible, fun.

From different chats on forums, it seems people feel rather apprehensive about Async programming particularly because of its seemingly daunting syntax. It just looks alien. This apprehension is what this tutorial should address.

**Key Ideas, APIs, and Techniques:**

Async doesn’t replace Coroutines. Instead, Async programming is another tool at our disposal.

Luckily, syntax and semantics come to our aid. There are good reasons to think that the right tool for the right job also has the right name. For instance, if you need to wait for something, what sounds more fitting: await or IEnumerable NameOfMethod? If you need to make a task and wait for it, what is more natural: await Task or StartCoroutine(DoSomethingDuringTime())? 😊

We should avoid this: "let’s create four factories that need four delegates each and two pairs of lambda expressions so you can add two numbers”. A better approach would be to teach one command, explain it, use it, show it, recap.

Async-await:
- comes from functional programming so… it’s beautiful and better XD
- preserves the call stack
- is cleaner in most cases => This can be explained in Composition

Coroutines:
- Unity can’t follow the track of IEnumerators order, so you lose the Control flow
- don’t return anything (because it’s not functional programming)
- are not good for composition (stack 20 tasks and you end up with a splitting headache and nasty callbacks)



I dare say, if this tutorial is fun, it will be the first fun tutorial about Async operations on the whole internet. 😁

Try to cover:
	- What’s asynchronous programming? Brief explanation
	- Comparing and contrasting Coroutines to Async. Briefly explaining IEnumerators and threading tasks if applicable
	- Explaining special keywords: Await, Async, Tasks, Tasks<T> (although Task<T> can be explained later)
	- Defining most useful methods: Task.Delay, TimeSpan, Task.Run,
		 very simple lambda expressions if needed, creating Tasks, Await, Async, Task.Whenall and so on
	- Explaining Return Types and Returning Values
	- Show how to Try-Catch errors
	- Include a simple stopwatch if you can
	- Async Composition (Task or Tasks that Await other Tasks)
	- Cancellation Token.
	- Drawbacks when Coroutines or Awaitables are not handled (canceled before quitting)
	- Why Coroutines are good > Why Async operations are sometimes better

Possible follow-ups:
	- Async over web-based tasks. For instance, awaiting mails or downloading packs.
	- Async for Addressables. For instance, loading and unloading Scene Async.


**Sample App Idea:**

Here are two great ideas to cover these topics: “Making a coffee” and “Win the race; the race is over.”

The first API: “Making a coffee” (or any recipe, for that matter)

This program is a small game about the process of making a nice cup of coffee.
Draw each component: a cup of coffee, a jug of water, coffee grains…  to use as a visual aid.

Explain the process of making a coffee through Tasks:
	*Fetch a cup
	*Fetch coffee grains
	*Process coffee grains
	*Boil water
	*Pour water into cup
	…There you have it

Say you want to introduce the await instruction. In that case, you can await for x amount of time for the water to boil.
Now, following the same example, you can introduce Task.delay, the semantics of await… and so on. Then, you can also introduce Composition. Now you have to wait for more than one Task. You can compare different results regarding the order of the Tasks.

The second API: “Win the race; the race is over”

This is a race game. Each car with its own speed. You can check the time each car crosses the finish line; as well as, the time they all have crossed.

Create some very super simple cars. They should have a simple script to move them at different speeds.
It is the same idea as in “Making a coffee API”: showing how the process of waiting for an Async composition. It will suffice to make 4 cars race to the finish line.

Say you want to introduce one of the most difficult topics: “cancellation”. Then you can explain it pretending a car is in the pit box or busted when the cancellation token is raised. Say you want to check if all Tasks have been completed, you can call Task.WhenAll and so on.

The API should be super simple because the focus is programming.

**References:**

http://www.stevevermeulen.com/index.php/2017/09/using-async-await-in-unity3d-2017/
https://blog.stephencleary.com/2012/02/async-and-await.html

## Brief

**Working Title:** Unity: Coroutines Vs Async

**Audience Level:**  Advanced

**Style:** Core Concept

**Motivation:**

Coroutines are a well used technique within Unity development, and something that many advanced users will be familiar with. Async was added as an option with the .NET update in Unity 2017. However, we don't have a tutorial on either feature on the site. Coroutines have been well covered for Kotlin, but not in Unity. 

The tutorial should cover both techniques, and also note on `Invoke` as another option. It should be a compare and contrast to cover the best practises, and help the reader understand which technique to use in different use cases.

**Key Ideas, APIs, and Techniques:**

- How to Start a Coroutine / Async Task.
- How to Pause(Yield/Wait) a Coroutine / Async Task.
- How to Stop a Coroutine / Async Task.
- How to Cancel a Coroutine / Async Task.
- How to Return from a Coroutine / Async Task.
- How to Handle Errors in a Coroutine / Async Task.

(Hint: the last two options are where Async excels)

Here's a great comparison image of the two techniques, taken from the first video in the References:
![Best practices: Async vs. coroutines - Unite Copenhagen](https://trello-attachments.s3.amazonaws.com/606ca8fa76e4503496ca5dd4/875x488/855880d768a4f9a30b5f549bbd1ddb32/chrome_kRGxaKLNxZ.png)

**Sample App Idea:**

Two ideas for a sample app:

1. An application that downloads assets & scenes, and loads them in to the environment at runtime, asynchronously. 
2. A game where the user can input a list of instructions to a robot/vehicle, which then runs through them as a ToDo list. (Totally remembering the [Roamer](https://youtu.be/TTox-Z37qz0) from my school days).

Either sample can also use UI and input as additional ways to introduce the logic. i.e; waiting for input, waiting for user to click "Accept" on a terms screen, animating the UI itself. 

**References:**

- [Best practices: Async vs. coroutines - Unite Copenhagen](https://youtu.be/7eKi6NKri6I)
- [Game Dev Beginner: Coroutines and how to use them](https://gamedevbeginner.com/coroutines-in-unity-when-and-how-to-use-them/)
- [John Tucker: Levelling up with Async/Await/Tasks](https://john-tucker.medium.com/unity-leveling-up-with-async-await-tasks-2a7971df9c57)
- [Steve Vermeulen: Async-Await instead of Coroutines in Unity 2017](http://www.stevevermeulen.com/index.php/2017/09/using-async-await-in-unity3d-2017/)
- [Unity API: Coroutine](https://docs.unity3d.com/ScriptReference/Coroutine.html)

cards.desc:
Have you heard of Flux?

http://bit.ly/1O9dpSx

Its a framework for a unidirectional data flow. The core princpal is data can only be modified from 1 source, and accessed from 1 source. I find it GREALTY reduces spagetti code and it decouples controllers from data manipulation. A controller just becomes an event dispatcher and all data manipulation is handled by the store:

Now I wanted to do a tutorial on UnityEvents, but this unidirectional model is 10x cooler than JUST a UnityEvents tutorial.

I was able to recreate Flux (which was designed for JS) to work with UnityEvents and UnityActions.

When you have some precious spare time take a look at the video linked and let me know if this is something we could turn into a tutorial. Its hella cool.

I implemented it in my game and my code is becoming a lot cleaner, clearer, and a lot closer to 1 function 1 responsibility (which I find MVC forces you to violate a lot as you scale your game).

cards.desc:
Pitfalls (I'll add more to this list as I remember them):

- Animated objects & characters need a parent GameObject, and their transform properties needs to be all zeroes. Only move, rotate & scale the parent, never directly manipulate the child.
- If you rotate a child GameObject, make sure the parent is unscaled. Rotation on an object with a non-uniformly scaled parent will cause weird scaling issues.
- When creating a huge world or plan on moving the character a lot in a single direction (like an endless runner game), move the world, not the character. Not doing this results in floating point errors which will make physics wonky in the best case and will jitter all meshes all around the place at its worst.
- Multiply all non-physics based movement, rotation and scale over time by Time.deltaTime. Not doing this makes the game frame dependent, so the speed at which things happen will do so much more quickly on powerful hardware and slowly on weak hardware like phones.
- For physics, only apply force, velocity and torque in FixedUpdate(). This will sync those calls with the PhysX engine underneath. You can increase the rate of the physics calls and the time it can take to calculate if you want more accurate (and more expensive) physics calculations.
- Avoid all Find() methods and **never** use them in Update(). These take a long time and will be slower the more GameObjects there are in your scene. Hook up as much as you can in the editor. If you must link up a bunch of GameObjects at runtime (spawning enemies for example) create a manager class with a list that can keep the references cached and let the let the enemies register and unregister themselves with that manager with OnEnable() & OnDisable() respectively. This is cheap and easy to manage. If that isn't viable, move the Find calls to Awake() and keep them to a minimum.
- If you're instantiating a lot of objects and destroying them again after a while, consider using pools instead. This will allow you to recycle the same objects, saving you some computation time. (link to pool tutorial)
- Avoid manipulating strings, creating lists and using LINQ in Update(). All of these create memory allocations which will cause the GC (garbage collector) to step in sooner than later with all kinds of hitches as a consequence. Opt to use StringBuilder to create complex strings, cache strings that will be reused in Awake() and pre-allocate lists and arrays on Awake(). Try to stay away from LINQ as much as possible for now. Most of those problems will belong to the past once we get a new version of Mono.
cards.name: Most Common Pitfalls In Unity And How To Avoid Them - Assigned to Eric

*Due Date*: We're rushing this article to capture tvOS buzz - aiming for tonight! :]
*Topic*: tvOS SDK: An iOS Developer’s Initial Impressions
*Length*: 4,000 words or less
*Audience*: iOS developers interested in developing for tvOS, and curious to find out how the tvOS SDK works. They probably watched the keynote but didn't dig into the docs or samples much yet, so would like a summary of what's going on. 
*RW Slant*: Excited about tvOS and the opportunities it offers for developers.

*Tips*: 

* The article we did that is most similar to the style you should aim for is this article: http://www.raywenderlich.com/89473/watchkit-initial-impressions

* Note how it covers the major aspects of watchOS that would be different or surprising for iOS developers, along with a bit of technical info for how it works.

* For your article, here are some major areas of tvOS that might be worth discussing in sections: 

  * *General info*: (Maybe split this into a few sections if necessary) What is the Apple TV and how much will it cost? Can we develop our own apps for this, and can people purchase them directly from the Apple TV? Can apps be just for Apple TV, or do they have to be universal? What's the difference between Xcode 7 and 7.1? When will Apple TV be released? How do you sign up for a developer kit and how much does it cost? 

  * *TVML, TVMLJS, TVMLKit*: What is this? Does every app need to use this, or is this just an optional thing? How does it work? What is the benefit of using this over developing apps in Interface Builder/Storyboards?

  * *TVServices & top shelf concept*: What is the top shelf? What should apps put in there (i.e. not just a pretty image, Apple's pushing apps to show dynamic content from their apps). How do you do this technically?

  * *Parallax images*: What are these and how can you create one? What should you use these for?

  * *Controller*: What are the new interactions available on the controller? What do you need to

cards.desc:
My name is Waqas Ahmad. I am from Pakistan and I have recently completed my Bachelors Degree in Computer Science from National University of Science and Technology Islamabad Pakistan. I love to play and make games. I have started learning unity during third year of my studies at university. I have learned different game making tools like Unity and cocos2dx. Moreover I have studied game development as my major subject for my degree.
       Now I am working as game developer at Sablo Studio (6 months experience). The game which I am really proud of is Word War.  The game is rather simple but the true task I faced while development was that the boss kept changing levels many times during development so the solution I came up with was to build a easy editor window from which my boss can easily drag and drop things as required to make levels according to its taste and it turned out really well and boss made all 25 levels himself.
       Moreover I use my free time to learn about game development. Like now I have learned about Shader programming using online book and created a mesh digging system for my upcoming game. I already use unity answers to help others and I will be happy to share my knowledge of unity with the world.

cards.desc:
Hi Enrique, 

The first phase of writing this tutorial for our site is to put together an outline. Check out this guide that explains the process and gives an example:

http://www.raywenderlich.com/tutorial-team/writing-guide-part-1 (password is tutteam)

Can you please put together an outline and send it to me by September 13? I’ll send any comments and then explain the next step.

Here is the format for our briefs.  Feel free to modify it as necessary. 


Topic: Your topic name

Audience: Beginner, Intermediate, or Advanced

Tutorial Briefing:

Explain the purpose of your tutorial and what people can expect to learn. 

Hints/Tips:

Include any references that in inspire or add useful information to your tutorial. 
For example, https://www.raywenderlich.com/795-introduction-to-unity-ui-part-1

If you have any questions, just let me know!

Annette

On Tue, 4 Sep 2018 at 21:24 Annette Marlette <annette@raywenderlich.com> wrote:
Hi Enrique,

This is Part 2 of your Unity tryout.

BTW, I've cc'ed Eric and bcc'ed Ray, Chris Belanger, and Manda Frederick on this note so they are aware Part 2 of your tryout is beginning.  

Our tryout process to join as an author is very simple - simply write a tutorial for our site. If it reaches our high quality level, we'll publish the tutorial and bring you fully on-board the team! It's similar to your Pre-Tryout except there is a longer word count limit (4K).

The first step is to choose a topic. Here are three possible ideas - please let me know if anything sounds interesting!

1. [Audience:TBD] [Prefabs] Introduction to the New Prefab Workflow
2. [Beginner] [AR] Introduction to ARKit in Unity
3. [Beginner] Most Common Pitfalls In Unity And How To Avoid Them

We're also open to any other good ideas you may have. A good idea is interesting to a wide audience, not already covered on the site, and focusing on a specific technique/technology.

Please reply by September 7 and let me know which idea is best with you. Don't start writing anything yet, just choose a topic for now. I'll then explain the next step!

Thanks,
Annette

cards.desc:
This topic on creating a replay system would be nice: https://trello.com/c/FrZE4ZJQ/156-advanced-creating-a-replay-system-in-unity

It's an advanced topic to explain how to record and play back interactions in games. The "game" itself can be as simple as moving from side to side and performing a simple action like jumping, crouching and/or shooting. The focus should be on recording those actions some way and playing it back.

**Post:** https://www.raywenderlich.com/wp-admin/post.php?post=244197&action=edit

Author: <Teddy Engel>
Tech Editor: <TBD by Team Lead>
Editor: April Rames
FPE: <TBD by Team Lead>

## Artwork

**Artwork Request:** https://trello.com/c/OlmaioKV

## Brief

**Working Title:** <Creating a Replay System in Unity>

**Audience Level:**  <Advanced>

**Prerequisites:** Basic Unity, Unity UI, Basic Unity 2D, Basic C#, File Saving / Loading

**Style:** <How-To>

- **How-To**:  Create a replay system in a non-deterministic game engine

**Motivation:** State-based replay systems work in any context (as long as you can read / write the state to replay), let you specify precisely what you want to replay or not, and are simpler to implement than input-based systems.

**Key Ideas, APIs, and Techniques:** State-based replay system + Memory Stream
 
**Sample App Idea:** Starring… BIRDY! - A simple 2D platformer scene starring a bird character (need to find a way to add ray-bans to the bird sprite I have). Styled with a retro / 8-bit look apart from the main sprite.
 
**References:**
http://www.elopezr.com/replay-system-using-unity/
https://www.gamasutra.com/blogs/AustonMontville/20141105/229437/Implementing_a_replay_system_in_Unity_and_how_Id_do_it_differently_next_time.php
https://www.gamasutra.com/view/feature/2029/developing_your_own_replay_system.php

## Brief
Topic: How to Implement Movement in Different Genres of Games in Unity
https://trello.com/c/z1blqJPI

Audience: Beginner

Tutorial Briefing:

Explain how to efficiently implement different ways of locomotion. From the way Mario moves and keeps his momentum to the flying spaceships in SHMUPS and the point-to-move movement of heroes in the Diablo series.
Cover 3-5 different ways of moving around and explain the choices you made for a particular method clearly.

Hints/Tips:

A few ideas to get you started:
- Click to rotate & move (diablo)
- 2D Platformer player controller (mario)
- Grid based movement (old school RPG, SRPG)
- Tank style movement (GTA 1 & 2)
